Arguments: - STEP_ID

Options: - less (--less) - Show less like output. - localize (--localize) - Convert UTC datetime to local timezone. - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: validate
docs.text:
Validate FILE containing step against a stage with STAGE_ID.

FILE is path/to/your/file that you want to validate.

STAGE_ID is an ID of the stage you want to validate the step against.

Arguments: - FILE - STAGE_ID

Options: - inventory_files (-i, --inventory-file) - Inventory file used to fill the template. Can be used multiple times. - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: workers
docs.text:
Manage Workers from here.

Options: - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: create
docs.text:
Create new Worker with NAME.

NAME of your Worker (will be used to match your Worker). For example: "MyCustomName".

Arguments: - NAME

Options: - description (-d, --description) - Description of your Worker (wrap in ""). - force (-f, --force) - Ignore, if Worker with the same parameter 'name' exists. - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: delete
docs.text:
Delete Worker with WORKER_ID saved in Cryton.

WORKER_ID is ID of the Worker you want to delete.

Arguments: - WORKER_ID

Options: - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: health-check
docs.text:
Check if Worker with WORKER_ID is online.

WORKER_ID is ID of the Worker you want to check.

Arguments: - WORKER_ID

Options: - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: list
docs.text:
List existing Workers.

Options: - parameter_filters (-f, --filter) - Filter results using returned parameters (for example id 1, name value). - localize (--localize) - Convert UTC datetime to local timezone. - limit (-l, --limit) - Number of results to return per page. - offset (-o, --offset) - The initial index from which to return the results. - less (--less) - Show less like output. - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: show
docs.text:
Show Worker with WORKER_ID.

WORKER_ID is ID of the Worker you want to see.

Arguments: - WORKER_ID

Options: - less (--less) - Show less like output. - localize (--localize) - Convert UTC datetime to local timezone. - help (--help) - Show this message and exit.

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text:
Cryton Frontend provides functionality for interacting with Cryton Core more easily and clearly than by using CLI.

By default, the Frontend is served at http://localhost:8080/.

Use the in-app help pages to learn about usage.

Update settings at runtime

It is possible to update the REST API host and port at runtime at http://localhost:8080/app/user/settings.

docs.title: Listing data
docs.text: You can list all Cryton data by using list pages in the navigation bar. Most important data can be found directly in the dashboard. Each data table provides functionality for sorting and filtering data.

docs.title: Creating objects
docs.text: You can create workers, templates, instances, and runs by using create pages in the navigation bar. Every object can be also deleted from its list page.

docs.title: Template creation
docs.text: You can create plan templates in the Plan templates > Create template. The whole creation process is documented in-app with an introduction page and additional help pages for every creation step.

docs.title: Run interaction
docs.text: The front end provides 2 ways to interact with runs. There is a quick interaction menu that you can access in Runs > List runs by clicking on a run. The interaction menu will expand under the run. Another way is to click on the eye icon next to the run which will take you to the run's page. There you can also view the current state of the run and its sub-parts, and modify the execution variables for each execution.

docs.title: Execution timeline
docs.text: You can view timelines of the run's executions by clicking on the clock icon next to a run on the list runs page or by clicking on the show timeline button on the run's page. The timeline shows the start, pause and finish times of the whole execution, stages, and steps. More details can be found in an in-app help page found inside the timeline tab.

docs.title: Theming
docs.text: The front end provides two color themes - light and dark. You can switch between them with a toggle button in the top bar.

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Cryton Frontend uses environment variables for its settings. Please update them to your needs.

Notice

For now, settings can be changed only for the npm installation. However, it is possible to update the API host and port at runtime at http://localhost:8080/app/user/settings.

Variables can be found in src/environments/. For production modify the environment.prod.ts file, else modify the environment.ts file.

docs.title: crytonRESTApiHost
docs.text:
Cryton Core's API address.

value default example string 127.0.0.1 cryton-hive

docs.title: crytonRESTApiPort
docs.text:
Cryton Core's API port.

value default example int 8000 8008

docs.title: refreshDelay
docs.text:
Sets artificial delay in milliseconds for refresh API requests.

What is this for?

Users usually react better if the requests don't happen instantly, but they can see a tiny bit of loading. Initial API request doesn't use delay, this is only for refreshing data

value default example int 300 500

docs.title: useHttps
docs.text:
Use SSL to connect to REST API.

value default example boolean false true

docs.title: REST API
docs.text:
This page provides information about the (self-hosted) interactive documentation of the Cryton REST API endpoints. It also provides a list of changes and some important notes.

To access the Swagger or Redoc pages, install and start the Cryton Hive application as described here or here.

Uploading files

Files must be uploaded as bytes and encoded using UTF-8.

docs.title: Swagger interactive documentation
docs.text: If you are interested in the Swagger interactive documentation, open the Cryton REST API or browse to the /doc endpoint. For example: http://127.0.0.1:8000/doc/.

docs.title: Redoc interactive documentation
docs.text: If you are interested in the Redoc interactive documentation, browse to the /redoc endpoint on Cryton REST API. For example: http://127.0.0.1:8000/redoc/.

docs.title: API changes
docs.text: There are no changes.

docs.title: Modules
docs.text:
As mentioned before, modules are Python scripts/packages that wrap tools and orchestrate them.

Module execution is done by Workers. All you need to do is to create a Step that will use your desired module.

Each module returns the following:

Parameter name Parameter description result ok - execution finished successfully fail - execution finished unsuccessfully error - an error occurred before the module could finish output Output or errors from the execution serialized_output Machine readable output in JSON that can accessed in other modules as input

Modules mentioned in the current section (check the navigation on the left) are bundled in the Worker installation and work out of the box.

docs.title: Installing unofficial modules
docs.text:
Installing unofficial module(s) is pretty straight forward.

  1. Find the desired module on PyPI or git (look for the cryton-modules- prefix)
  2. Install the module(s)
pipxpip 
pipx inject cryton <package>

pipx inject cryton git+<git-url>

Check here for examples.

Activate the virtual environment (source /path/to/venv/bin/activate) or use its PIP executable (/path/to/venv/bin/pip).

pip install <package>

pip install git+<git-url>

Check here for more information about installing packages and here for installing packages from VCS.

  • Since the version 2.0.0, installing modules using the modules directory is deprecated

  • Do not forget to check the instructions of the package you're about to install

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Module orchestrates Atomic Red Team using the Invoke-Atomic Powershell module.

It also gives you the option to select or install Powershell on the target system.

NOTE: OSX is unsupported.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Powershell on the target system and a valid/working Metasploit session on the target system.

If the target system is Windows, make sure to update the Virus & threat protections settings.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: technique
docs.text:
ID of the Atomic technique (possibly with test IDs defined using short form).

Name Type Required Default value Example value technique string ✓ T1222.002 T1222.002-1,2

docs.title: test_guids
docs.text:
Test GUIDs to run.

Name Type Required Default value Example value test_guids array[string] ✗ ["34...-690adf36a135", "fc...-381f5c35aff3"]

docs.title: parameters
docs.text:
Input arguments for the test(s).

Name Type Required Default value Example value parameters object ✗ {"numeric_mode": "700"}

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Custom Atomic command.

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ Invoke-AtomicTest T1222.001 -InputArgs @{"a"="b"}

docs.title: session_id
docs.text:
Metasploit session ID to use.

Name Type Required Default value Example value session_id integer ✓ 1

docs.title: powershell
docs.text:
Powershell related options.

Name Type Required Default value Example value powershell object ✗ {} {"install": true}

Only one of the two following properties can be set.

docs.title: executable
docs.text:
Path to Powershell executable.

Name Type Required Default value Example value executable string ✗ powershell.exe

docs.title: install
docs.text:
Whether to auto install Powershell.

Name Type Required Default value Example value install boolean ✗ false true

docs.title: Execute technique and all of its tests (including Powershell installation)
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: atomic_red_team
  arguments:
    session_id: 1
    technique: T1222.002
    powershell:
      install: true

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "PathToAtomicsFolder = /home/test/AtomicRedTeam/atomics\n\nExecuting test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\nchmod: cannot access '/tmp/AtomicRedTeam/atomics/T1222.002': No such file or directory\nExit code: 1\nDone executing test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\n", 
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Execute specific test with custom parameters
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: atomic_red_team
  arguments:
    session_id: 1
    technique: T1222.002
    test_guids: 
      - 34ca1464-de9d-40c6-8c77-690adf36a135
    parameters:
      numeric_mode: 700
      file_or_folder: /tmp/file

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "PathToAtomicsFolder = /home/test/AtomicRedTeam/atomics\n\nExecuting test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\nchmod: cannot access '/tmp/AtomicRedTeam/atomics/T1222.002': No such file or directory\nExit code: 1\nDone executing test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\n", 
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Run custom Atomic command
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: atomic_red_team
  arguments:
    session_id: 1
    command: Invoke-AtomicTest T1222.001

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "PathToAtomicsFolder = /home/test/AtomicRedTeam/atomics\n\nExecuting test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\nchmod: cannot access '/tmp/AtomicRedTeam/atomics/T1222.002': No such file or directory\nExit code: 1\nDone executing test: T1222.002-1 chmod - Change file or folder mode (numeric mode)\n", 
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: Not available at the moment.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
A module that allows local and remote command execution.

The module is used to run a single shell command. By default, the command is executed locally. If you specify a session, it will be executed in the respective session's context.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: In case you want to execute code remotely, Metasploit must be accessible from Worker it will be executed on.

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Command to execute.

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ whoami

docs.title: timeout
docs.text:
Timeout for the command (in seconds).

Name Type Required Default value Example value timeout integer ✗ 60

docs.title: session_id
docs.text:
Metasploit session to use.

Name Type Required Default value Example value session_id integer ✗ 1

docs.title: serialize_output
docs.text:
Try to parse the output of the command into serialized_output.

Name Type Required Default value Example value serialize_output boolean ✗ false true

docs.title: force_shell
docs.text:
Run the command in shell even in a Meterpreter session. To run the command in the Meterpreter shell (if available), set this to false.

Name Type Required Default value Example value force_shell boolean ✗ true false

docs.title: Read file on remote system using session
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: command
  arguments:
    command: cat /etc/passwd
    session_id: 1

Output: 

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "<contents of passwd file on target>",
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Meterpreter vs shell session
docs.text: By default, if you specified a session, this module will try to execute the provided command in a shell. For more details about different sessions, see here.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text:
Automatic output serialization is an experimental feature. It allows you to take the output and use it in other modules in the form of a serialized_output. For this to work, the command output must be a valid JSON ("some text", {"a": "b"}, ["a", "b"]).

It is in an experimental state primarily due to the randomness of the MSF shells and Windows combination. If you encounter any errors, please submit an issue.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
whoami on Linux (Debian): echo \\"$(whoami)\\" 

{
  "output": "\"username\"",
  "serialized_output": {"auto_serialized": "username"}
}

whoami on Windows 10: Powershell -C "whoami | ConvertTo-Json" 

{
  "output": "\"username\"",
  "serialized_output": {"auto_serialized": "username"}
}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Module orchestrates Empire. It allows you to deploy and use its agents.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Empire C2 server must be accessible from Worker it will be executed on.

docs.title: agent_name
docs.text:
Name of the deployed agent.

Name Type Required Default value Example value agent_name string ✓ myAgent

docs.title: action
docs.text:
Which type of action you want to perform.

Current options are:

  • deploy - deploy a new agent
  • execute-command - execute a command on an existing agent
  • execute-module - execute an Empire module on an existing agent
Name Type Required Default value Example value action string ✓ deploy Deploy agentExecute commandExecute module

docs.title: session_id
docs.text:
Metasploit session to use.

Name Type Required Default value Example value session_id integer ✓ 1

docs.title: listener
docs.text:
Arguments used for listener creation.

Name Type Required Default value Example value listener object ✓ {"name": "my-name"}

docs.title: name
docs.text:
Name of listener in Empire for identification. If listener with this name already exists in Empire, it will be used for stager generation.

Name Type Required Default value Example value name string ✓ myName

docs.title: port
docs.text:
Port on which should be listener communicating with Agents.

Name Type Required Default value Example value port integer ✗ 80 8080

docs.title: type
docs.text:
Type of the listener.

Name Type Required Default value Example value type string ✗ http smb

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional adjustable parameters for creating listener. More on here.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options object ✗ {"BindIP": "0.0.0.0"}

docs.title: stager
docs.text:
Arguments used for stager creation.

Name Type Required Default value Example value stager object ✓ {"type": "multi/bash"}

docs.title: type
docs.text:
Type of stager that should be generated in form of path. For stager types look here.

Name Type Required Default value Example value type string ✓ multi/bash

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional adjustable parameters for generating stager. Parameters can be viewed in individual stager python files or through Empire client.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options object ✗ {"Language": "python"}

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Command to execute on the agent.

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ whoami

docs.title: module
docs.text:
Arguments used for Empire module execution.

Name Type Required Default value Example value module object ✓ {"name": "collection/sniffer"}

docs.title: name
docs.text:
Name of the Empire module in form of a path. Available Empire modules here.

Name Type Required Default value Example value name string ✓ collection/sniffer

docs.title: arguments
docs.text:
Additional arguments for the Empire module.

Name Type Required Default value Example value arguments object ✗ {"IpFilter": "127.0.0.1"}

docs.title: Deploy agent
docs.text:
Input:

my-step:
  module: empire
  arguments:
    action: deploy
    agent_name: MyAgent
    session_id: 1
    listener:
      name: testing
    stager:
      type: multi/bash

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "Agent 'MyAgent' deployed on target 192.168.61.12.",
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Execute command on agent
docs.text:
Input:

my-step:
  module: empire
  arguments:
    action: execute-command
    agent_name: MyAgent
    command: whoami

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "{'agent': 'E5XSKQ4F', 'command': 'whoami', 'results': 'victim', 'taskID': 2, 'user_id': 1, 'username': 'empireadmin'}",
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Execute module on agent
docs.text:
Input:

my-step:
  module: empire
  arguments:
    action: execute-module
    agent_name: MyAgent
    module:
      name: collection/sniffer
      arguments:
        IpFilter: 192.168.33.12
        PortFilter: 1234

Output:

{
  "result": "ok",
  "output": "<output from the module execution>",
  "serialized_output": {}
}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Only the 4.10.0 version is supported.

  • Some Metasploit sessions may be unsuitable for deploying Empire agents
  • Make sure the Empire host is set correctly in the scenario and is reachable from the target
  • Currently, the multi/launcher option is the recommended stager for use with Windows machines
  • For Empire stagers to work on newer versions of Windows OS, you need to disable all firewall and antivirus protection on the target

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: The output is not serialized.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
A module for web fuzzing using the FFUF tool.

This module runs FFUF on given target and returns a file with found directories.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: FFUF must be installed.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: target
docs.text:
Scan target.

Name Type Required Default value Example value target string ✓ http://127.0.0.1:8000/FUZZ

docs.title: wordlist
docs.text:
The wordlist for fuzzing the webserver.

Name Type Required Default value Example value wordlist string ✓ /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional FFUF parameters.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options string ✗ -X POST

docs.title: serialize_output
docs.text:
Use FFUF's serialization (-of json -o file).

Name Type Required Default value Example value serialize_output boolean ✗ true false

docs.title: command
docs.text:
FFUF command to run with syntax as in command line (with executable).

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ ffuf -u http://127.0.0.1/FUZZ

docs.title: Example with serialized output
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: ffuf
  arguments:
    target: {{ target }}
    wordlist: "/usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt"
    options: -X POST

Output: 

{"time":"2023-05-16T12:04:36+02:00","config":{"sni":"","url":"http://172.16.169.128/FUZZ","json":false,"rate":0,"delay":{"value":"0.00"},"fmode":"or","http2":false,"mmode":"or","quiet":false,"colors":false,"method":"POST","cmdline":"ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt -u http://172.16.169.128/FUZZ -of json -o /tmp/cryton-ffuf-1684231474.215272.tmp -X POST","headers":{},"maxtime":0,"threads":40,"timeout":10,"verbose":false,"debuglog":"","matchers":{"Mutex":{},"Filters":{},"Matchers":{"status":{"value":"200,204,301,302,307,401,403,405,500"}},"IsCalibrated":false,"PerDomainFilters":{}},"postdata":"","proxyurl":"","scrapers":"all","stop_403":false,"stop_all":false,"inputmode":"clusterbomb","recursion":false,"wordlists":["/usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt"],"configfile":"","extensions":[],"ignorebody":false,"inputshell":"","outputfile":"/tmp/cryton-ffuf-1684231474.215272.tmp","maxtime_job":0,"requestfile":"","scraperfile":"","stop_errors":false,"cmd_inputnum":100,"outputformat":"json","requestproto":"https","inputproviders":[{"name":"wordlist","value":"/usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt","keyword":"FUZZ","template":""}],"noninteractive":false,"replayproxyurl":"","autocalibration":false,"outputdirectory":"","recursion_depth":0,"follow_redirects":false,"recursion_strategy":"default","OutputSkipEmptyFile":false,"autocalibration_keyword":"FUZZ","autocalibration_perhost":false,"autocalibration_strings":[],"dirsearch_compatibility":false,"autocalibration_strategy":"basic","ignore_wordlist_comments":false},"results":[],"commandline":"ffuf -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt -u http://172.16.169.128/FUZZ -of json -o /tmp/cryton-ffuf-1684231474.215272.tmp -X POST"}

docs.title: Example with text output
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: ffuf
  arguments:
    target: {{ target }}
    options: --max-threads 7
    serialize_output: False

Output: 

/'___\ /'___\ /'___\ /\ \__/ /\ \__/ __ __ /\ \__/ \ \ ,__\\ \ ,__\/\ \/\ \ \ \ ,__\ \ \ \_/ \ \ \_/\ \ \_\ \ \ \ \_/ \ \_\ \ \_\ \ \____/ \ \_\ \/_/ \/_/ \/___/ \/_/ v2.0.0-dev ________________________________________________ :: Method : POST :: URL : http://172.16.169.128/FUZZ :: Wordlist : FUZZ: /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/small.txt :: Output file : /tmp/cryton-ffuf-1684231474.215272.tmp :: File format : json :: Follow redirects : false :: Calibration : false :: Timeout : 10 :: Threads : 40 :: Matcher : Response status: 200,204,301,302,307,401,403,405,500 ________________________________________________ [2K:: Progress: [40/959] :: Job [1/1] :: 0 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:00] :: Errors: 0 :: [2K:: Progress: [492/959] :: Job [1/1] :: 0 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:00] :: Errors: 0 :: [2K:: Progress: [959/959] :: Job [1/1] :: 0 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:00] :: Errors: 0 :: [2K:: Progress: [959/959] :: Job [1/1] :: 121 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:01] :: Errors: 0 ::

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: Output is serialized by FFUF itself.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This module implements attacking capabilities of the Medusa bruteforce tool.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Medusa must be installed.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: target
docs.text:
Bruteforce target.

Name Type Required Default value Example value target string ✓ 127.0.0.1

docs.title: mod
docs.text:
mod (service) to attack.

Name Type Required Default value Example value mod string ✗ ssh ftp

docs.title: tasks
docs.text:
Number of login pairs tested concurrently.

Name Type Required Default value Example value tasks integer ✗ 4 8

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional Medusa parameters.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options string ✗ -t 3

docs.title: credentials
docs.text:
Group for credentials input.

Name Type Required Default value Example value credentials object ✓ {"combo_file": "/path/to/file"}

Specify either combo_file or one of each username (username/username_file) and password (password/password_file) parameters:

docs.title: username
docs.text:
Username to bruteforce.

Name Type Required Default value Example value username string ✗ username

docs.title: username_file
docs.text:
Absolute path to file with usernames to bruteforce.

Name Type Required Default value Example value username_file string ✗ /path/to/file

docs.title: password
docs.text:
Password to bruteforce.

Name Type Required Default value Example value password string ✗ password

docs.title: password_file
docs.text:
Absolute path to file with passwords to bruteforce.

Name Type Required Default value Example value password_file string ✗ /path/to/file

docs.title: combo_file
docs.text:
Absolute path to file with login pairs to bruteforce. The file should be in format username:password. More information can be found here.

Name Type Required Default value Example value combo_file string ✗ /path/to/file

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Medusa command to run with syntax as in command line (with executable).

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ medusa -u user -p pass -h 127.0.0.1 -M ssh

docs.title: SSH bruteforce
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: medusa
  arguments:
    target: {{ target }}
    raw_output: true
    credentials:
      username: vagrant
      password: vagrant
    tasks: 4

Output: 

{
  "result": "ok", 
  "output": "Medusa v2.2 [http://www.foofus.net] (C) JoMo-Kun / Foofus Networks <jmk@foofus.net>\n\nACCOUNT CHECK: [ssh] Host: 192.168.56.3 (1 of 1, 0 complete) User: vagrant (1 of 1, 0 complete) Password: vagrant (1 of 1 complete)\nACCOUNT FOUND: [ssh] Host: 192.168.56.3 User: vagrant Password: vagrant [SUCCESS]\n", 
  "serialized_output": {"username": "vagrant", "password": "vagrant", "all_credentials": [{"username": "vagrant", "password": "vagrant"}]}
}

docs.title: Custom command
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: medusa
  arguments:
    command: medusa -t 4 -u vagrant -p vagrant -h {{ target }} -M ssh

Output: 

{
  "result": "ok", 
  "output": "Medusa v2.2 [http://www.foofus.net] (C) JoMo-Kun / Foofus Networks <jmk@foofus.net>\n\nACCOUNT CHECK: [ssh] Host: 192.168.56.3 (1 of 1, 0 complete) User: vagrant (1 of 1, 0 complete) Password: vagrant (1 of 1 complete)\nACCOUNT FOUND: [ssh] Host: 192.168.56.3 User: vagrant Password: vagrant [SUCCESS]\n", 
  "serialized_output": {"username": "vagrant", "password": "vagrant", "all_credentials": [{"username": "vagrant", "password": "vagrant"}]}
}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text:
Only the credentials are serialized. They're parsed from the output.

serialized_output contains:

Parameter name Parameter description username First username found during bruteforce. password First password found during bruteforce. all_credentials List of dictionaries containing all the credentials found in bruteforce.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Module orchestrates Metasploit Framework.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Metasploit must be accessible from Worker it will be executed on.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: module_name
docs.text:
Name of Metasploit module.

Name Type Required Default value Example value module_name string ✓ unix/irc/unreal_ircd_3281_backdoor

docs.title: datastore
docs.text:
Datastore options (variables) to use for the execution. Basically an equivalent to set OPTION value.

Name Type Required Default value Example value datastore object ✗ {"RHOST": "127.0.0.1"}

docs.title: commands
docs.text:
Custom set of commands to execute in an order in the Metasploit console.

Name Type Required Default value Example value commands array[string] ✓ ["use multi/handler", "run -z"]

docs.title: timeout
docs.text:
Number of seconds to wait before the module execution will be terminated.

Name Type Required Default value Example value timeout integer ✗ 300

my-step:
  module: metasploit

    commands:
      - db_nmap --top-ports 100 {{ target }}

docs.title: Upgrade shell session
docs.text:
my-step:
  module: metasploit
  arguments:
    module_name: multi/manage/shell_to_meterpreter
    datastore:
      LHOST: {{ attacker_host }}
      SESSION: 1

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Session types
docs.text:
Metasploit Framework currently supports two types of sessions.

The first is a shell session, in which you can run shell commands without limitations.

The second is called Meterpreter session. It allows you to use it's provided commands, such as ifconfig or sysinfo. To run a command in a shell, you need to use the execute command with the -f, -i, and -a options (execute -f <command> -i -a <arguments>). In some cases, the command execution may fail. Before creating a plan, make sure it works for your target system/exploit and a correct payload is used.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text:
Only the session ID is serialized.

serialized_output contains:

Parameter name Parameter description session_id ID of the created session (only if created).

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
A module for scanning using the nmap tool.

By default, it scans the most common ports and returns a list with all ports and their parameters.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Nmap must be installed.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: target
docs.text:
Scan target.

Name Type Required Default value Example value target string ✓ 127.0.0.1

docs.title: ports
docs.text:
List of individual ports or ranges to scan.

Name Type Required Default value Example value ports array[integer] ✗ Top 100 common ports. [1-300, 443]

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional Nmap parameters.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options string ✗ -T4 -sV

docs.title: command
docs.text:
Nmap command to run with syntax as in command line (with executable).

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ nmap localhost

docs.title: serialize_output
docs.text:
Option to serialize output to JSON. This option will add -oX - parameter to the command (if not already there).

Name Type Required Default value Example value serialize_output boolean ✗ true false

docs.title: timeout
docs.text:
Timeout for the command (in seconds).

Name Type Required Default value Example value timeout integer ✗ 60 200

docs.title: port_parameters
docs.text:
Check if found ports match your desired parameters. If the port with desired parameters is not found, the module will result in failure.

Name Type Required Default value Example value port_parameters object ✗ {"portid": "22"}

Possible options:

---
protocol: tcp
portid: '22'
state: open
reason: syn-ack
reason_ttl: '0'
service:
  name: ssh
  product: OpenSSH
  version: 6.6.1p1 Ubuntu 2ubuntu2.13
  extrainfo: Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0
  ostype: Linux
  method: probed
  conf: '10'
cpe:
- cpe:/a:openbsd:openssh:6.6.1p1
- cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel
scripts: []

All options try to find string in the nmap serialized output, and they are non-case sensitive. For example if the cpe in the nmap output would be cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel, cpe: -linux in port_parameters would match it successfully.

docs.title: Example with predefined inputs
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: nmap
  arguments:
    target: {{ target }}
    ports:
      - 1-30
      - "80"
    port_parameters:
      - protocol: tcp
        portid: '80'
        state: open
        reason: syn-ack
        reason_ttl: '0'
        service:
          name: http
          product: Apache httpd
          version: 2.4.7
          method: probed
          conf: '10'
        cpe: 
          - apache
    options: -T4 -sV

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: Output is serialized by Nmap itself.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: A module for executing scripts (Python, sh, bash, ...).

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: There are no specific prerequisites.

docs.title: script_path
docs.text:
Full path to the script.

Name Type Required Default value Example value script_path string ✓ /tmp/script.py

docs.title: script_arguments
docs.text:
Optional arguments for the script.

Name Type Required Default value Example value script_arguments string ✗ -arg1 example

docs.title: executable
docs.text:
What should be used to execute the script.

Name Type Required Default value Example value executable string ✓ /usr/bin/python3

docs.title: serialize_output
docs.text:
Try to parse the output of the script into serialized_output.

Name Type Required Default value Example value serialize_output boolean ✗ false true

docs.title: timeout
docs.text:
Timeout for the command (in seconds).

Name Type Required Default value Example value timeout integer ✗ 60 30

docs.title: Run Python script
docs.text:
Input: 

my-step:
  module: script
  arguments:
    script_path: /tmp/example.py
    script_arguments: -t {{ target }}
    executable: python3
    timeout: 30

Output: 

{
  "serialized_output": {},
  "output": "script output",
  "result": "ok"
}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: Automatic output serialization is an experimental feature. It allows you to take the output and use it in other modules in the form of a serialized_output. For this to work, the command output must be a valid JSON ("some text", {"a": "b"}, ["a", "b"]).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: A module for scanning WordPress pages using the WPScan tool.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: WPScan must be installed.

docs.title: Input parameters
docs.text: SimpleCustom

docs.title: target
docs.text:
Scan target.

Name Type Required Default value Example value target string ✓ http://127.0.0.1:8000/

docs.title: api_token
docs.text:
The WPScan API Token to display vulnerability data, available at https://wpscan.com/profile.

Name Type Required Default value Example value api_token string ✗

docs.title: options
docs.text:
Additional WPScan parameters.

Name Type Required Default value Example value options string ✗ --max-threads 7

docs.title: serialize_output
docs.text:
Use WPScan's serialization (-f json).

Name Type Required Default value Example value serialize_output boolean ✗ true false

docs.title: command
docs.text:
WPScan command to run with syntax as in command line (with executable).

Name Type Required Default value Example value command string ✓ wpscan --url http://127.0.0.1:8000/ -f json

For the scan result to be in the serialized_output, use -f json parameter.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: So far so good.

docs.title: Output serialization
docs.text: Output is serialized by WPScan itself.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: Before starting the applications, make sure to check out the settings page. In case of a misconfiguration the application may not start or Worker and Hive may not communicate. If that happens check the command output or logs.

docs.title: Hive
docs.text:
Use the following to invoke the application: 

cryton-hive

You should see a help page: 

Usage: cryton-hive [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Cryton Hive.

Options:
  ...

To learn about each command's options use: 

cryton-hive <your command> --help

To migrate the database and start the application use: 

cryton-hive start --migrate-database

REST API is by default running at http://0.0.0.0:8000 (interactive documentation at http://0.0.0.0:8000/doc).

To serve the REST API on a different host/port, use the --bind option: 

cryton-hive start --bind <address>:<port>

Run it in the background

Use the nohup command: 

nohup cryton-hive start > /tmp/hive_std_out 2>&1 &

To stop it, find its processes and stop them: 

ps -aux | grep cryton-hive
kill <PID> <PID>

docs.title: Worker
docs.text:
Use the following to invoke the application: 

cryton-worker

You should see a help page: 

Usage: cryton-worker [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Cryton Worker.

Options:
  ...

To learn about each command's options use: 

cryton-worker <your command> --help

To start the Worker use: 

cryton-worker start

Run it in the background

Use the nohup command: 

nohup cryton-worker start > /tmp/worker_std_out 2>&1 &

To stop it, find its processes and kill them: 

ps -aux | grep cryton-worker
kill <PID> <PID>

docs.title: CLI
docs.text:
Use the following command to invoke the application: 

cryton-cli

You should see a help page: 

Usage: cryton-cli [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Wrapper for Hive's REST API.

Options:
  ...

To learn about each command's options use: 

cryton-cli <your command> --help

docs.title: Workflows
docs.text: The current page describes the ideal sequence of steps to use when you want to use Cryton to automate the attacks.

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text:
Once you have your infrastructure, install Cryton onto it:

  1. Deploy and start Hive
  2. Deploy and start Worker(s)
  3. Deploy CLI or Frontend
  4. Make sure it works:
    • To ensure your deployment works, try to perform a successful healthcheck on your Worker(s) using CLI, frontend, or possibly REST API
    • Additionally, check the Hive and Worker(s) output if there are any errors

Tips

  • In case you are hosting a Cyber defense exercise with an infrastructure for each team, use one Worker per team

docs.title: Attack planning
docs.text:
Every Run can be described by a simple formula: 

plan template + inventory = Plan instance
Plan instance + Worker = Plan execution
Plan instance + Workers = Run

Which results in the following steps:

  1. Design a plan template (scenario)
  2. Create a Plan instance
  3. Register the Worker(s)
  4. Create a Run
  5. Schedule or execute the Run
  6. Get the Run report
